Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Ground-based Measurements to Constrain Aerosol-Cloud-Precipitation Interactions in West Coast United States Storms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
This research seeks to characterize aerosol particles acting as cloud condensation nuclei (CCN) and ice nucleating particles (INPs) during wintertime storms along the west coast of the U.S. Specifically the researchers will participate in CalWater-2/ACAPEX field campaign with a combination of ground measurements at Bodega Bay, CA and airborne instruments studying the Atmospheric River (AR) phenomena and the impact of aerosols on wintertime precipitation in the Sierra Mountains of California.


Intellectual Merit
These ground-based and in situ airborne measurements will improve our fundamental understanding of the role of biological and other aerosol types in enhancing or suppressing orographic precipitation over the western U.S. during winter. A variety of instruments will be used to directly and remotely measure these aerosols. The results should aid the cloud microphysics community through improved understanding of ice formation in clouds at temperatures warmer than -20C. This study will be conducted in collaboration with the Department of Energy (DoE) and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) during the CalWater-2 field campaign. The ground- and ship-based data will be combined with airborne data to develop a four-dimensional view of Cloud Condensation Nuclei (CCN) and Ice Nucleating Particle (INP) concentrations. Data sets will be integrated into a description of the influences of these aerosols on winter and early spring precipitation in the Sierra Mountains of California.


Broader Impacts
This project will support the training of Ph.D. students from two universities (Colorado State University and North Carolina State University) using advanced instrumentation including confocal fluorescence microscopy and scanning electron microscopy. With the ongoing drought in the western United States this study is both timely and critical in advancing our understanding of biological and other aerosol types on wintertime precipitation in the Sierra Mountains. As a major source region of the U.S. food supply, an improved understanding of the role of these aerosols on wintertime precipitation has broad implications on the resulting spring and summer water management policy in California.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported participation in the Calwater field study, which took place in early 2015. The main emphasis of this Collaborative Project was to conduct a comprehensive characterization of cloud-active particles that can influence precipitation in the Sierra Nevada Mountain range with resulting impacts on regional water resources. The lack of such information hampers a comprehensive assessment of the roles of pollution and of biogenic particles, whether local in origin or transported across the Pacific, in affecting precipitation in the associated watersheds.

The specific objectives of this project were to participate in the field study at the Bodega Bay research site in California by making continuous measurements of aerosol properties and also collecting samples for later laboratory analyses. As part of this deployment, aerosol size distribution and cloud condensation nuclei data were collected. Also particles were sampled into liquid and precipitation samples were collected from landfalling winter storms. These samples were analyzed for the number of ice nucleating particles. A strong correlation between ice nucleating particle concentration active at temperatures > -20 deg C and fluorescent biological aerosol particles was found. Fluorescent particle concentrations showed a diurnal cycle that is consistent with the nocturnal collapse of the boundary layer. Meteorological analysis suggests that the source of the fluorescent particles is continental and not marine in origin. Fluorescent particle and ice nucleating particle concentrations increased substantially after rainfall, consistent with previous findings. Analysis of the INP concentration from samples of storm water from a landfalling winter storm showed that the oceanic airmass was significantly lower in ice nuclei concentrations relative to continental precipitation.

The project has provided opportunity for several undergraduate students to work with a graduate student and the principal investigator on laboratory measurements of ice nucleating particles. The benefits of undergraduate research on student attitudes and retention are widely known. To date, all of the students either graduated or remain on track for graduation in the B.S. program at NC State University. A graduate student at the M.S. level was trained in conducting field experiments, laboratory work, scientific data processing, exploratory data analysis, and publication writing. Two outreach lectures were given to students at Swane county 4-H through the North Carolina cooperative extension. The students were setup with laboratory equipment to collect rainwater samples, and instructed how rainwater samples can be used to learn about the chemical composition of the atmosphere.
